Award.AwardTitle: Boston University Conference on Language Development 2012-2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The Boston University Conference on Language Development will be held at Boston University each November from 2012 through 2016. The conference is an internationally recognized meeting for researchers in the areas of first and second language acquisition, bilingualism, language disorders, and literacy development. It is attended by 500-600 researchers from around the world each year, providing a venue for dissemination of research, collaboration, and networking. The attendees typically include an even mix of young and senior researchers. The presentations are chosen by anonymous peer review, with a published proceedings. Since 1976, the faculty and students of Boston University's Applied Linguistics Program have organized and run the conference. Dr. Paul Hagstrom leads the team of organizers for the 2012 conference. The National Science Foundation award contributes to the support of the student organizers, travel assistance for student presenters, and accessibility through sign language interpreters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided support for five years of the Boston University Conference on Language Development, from 2012-2016. This premier annual international conference brings in over 500 scholars each year, from several disciplines including linguistics, psychology, cognitive science, neuroscience, anthropology, education, and communication disorders. Undergraduate and graduate students as well as faculty are among the presenters. The research presented is of extremely high quality, as ensured by a rigorous review process in which each submission is rated by five external reviewers from a panel of almost 200 international experts. The Principal Investigators of the award oversee a team of dedicated students in managing all aspects of the conference.

In addition to the accepted program of oral and poster presentations, the conference program includes two invited speakers, two symposia selected from several submissions, a funding workshop presented by representatives from the National Science Foundation and the National Institutes of Health, a book exhibit, and, in recent years, a professional development workshop for students.

This award specifically funded three aspects of BUCLD: stipends for the Boston University students who organize the conference, travel awards for students who are presenting posters or papers, and professional ASL interpretation for deaf attendees. BUCLD has a long-standing commitment to promoting and supporting student involvement in the conference and in the field, as well as ensuring accessibiliity for deaf attendees.
